ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Deaf history in regards to education, activism, and legislation. I also learned how to debate in formal register ASL.
I learned a TON about Deaf culture, Deaf epistemology, and the history of Deaf education and legislation in America.

This course focused on laws and legislation affecting the Deaf community. It is more of a history and ethics course than a vocabulary course. However, you do learn a lot of vocabulary relating to Deaf issues.
Understanding of issues in the deaf community

Knowledge about the history of deaf education/pedagogy, disability legislation, and Deaf identity. Also focused on presentation skills and use of media to connect with the Deaf community. Practicing vocabulary/formal ASL register learning L1-4.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The material of the course is extremely relevant to today, and the history component of the class taught me a lot about the different ways d/Deaf people have been perceived in society and by the government. I loved the class discussions we had sitting around the table together. 
One thing that could've made this class better would be more time engaging with immediate issues in the Deaf community. We spent a lot of time at the beginning of the semester learning about history, and I enjoyed that--but I wish we could've discussed more recent issues as well.
Strengths: classroom debates, small class size, relevant topics. Weaknesses: would have liked to have more feedback on our own signing to improve throughout the semester.

This class is amazing for practicing ASL and learning how to form arguments and express more complex thoughts. I did feel like I wasn't able to engage as deeply with the material as I wanted to at times though.
Difficult to stay engaged for 75 minute classes

Biggest strength is Dr. S and her interest in the subject. Some of my favorite moments in the class were when we would discuss the way Deaf issues affect her and how she feels about them. Overall, the course is pretty geared towards the units, I would have liked some more vocabulary like in ASL 1-4. I was learning signs more informally, but not as much as in the earlier levels.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I really enjoyed this course and I think the small class size really allows you practice ASL in conversations that are more formal and serious, which I never had before in ASL classrooms.
Yes! I would keep taking ASL classes at Yale if there were more for me to take...which is to say, if you are in L4 and thinking about this class, you absolutely should take it.

I would definitely recommend this course!! Its a great culmination to your ASL courses at Yale. I think this course is valuable because of the community aspect. I definitely learned a lot from the lectures but enjoy random class discussions the most.
Yes, if they have taken the previous asl courses

Yes! I loved my time in the ASL program at Yale and especially loved having a small class dedicated to learning about Deaf issues. I would recommend this class to another student interested in spending more time exploring and discussing Deaf education and policy.
